body: Did you crop your labeled data? This is a very important step for small GPUs; see the related issue #918.
@jeylau I think so.  The original video is 1920 x 1080.  It was cropped into 400 x 400 pieces.
Perhaps try passing `allow_growth=True` to `deeplabcut.train_network` or decreasing `global_scale` in the pose_cfg.yaml; this may help ðŸ¤”

@jeylau Oh right!  Thank you for bringing up `deeplabcut.train_network(path_config_file, allow_growth=True)`. I read about this in other posts (i.e. #1011 an #1050), and I forgot to ask about the implementation of it.  Since we are using the GUI, how do I add `allow_growth=True` to `deeplabcut.train_network`?  Sorry for the dumb question...

since you made your project already, you can skip the GUI to train. Simply launch the conda env, then:
```python
ipython
import deeplabcut
path_config_file = 'C:\\yourpath\\config.yaml'
deeplabcut.train_network(path_config_file, allow_growth=True)
```
@MMathisLab I will try that tomorrow and get back to you. Thank you!

@MMathisLab The training is working! A message popped up indicating that we may need a larger GPU. This should not affect the training performance, right? @MMathisLab Yeah!! I am so glad that it's running!  I have a quick question.  In the GUI, I could specify how many iterations to run.  In the terminal, do I just stop the training by `Ctrl+C`?

> since you made your project already, you can skip the GUI to train. Simply launch the conda env, then:
> 
> ```python
> ipython
> import deeplabcut
> path_config_file = 'C:\\yourpath\\config.yaml'
> deeplabcut.train_network(path_config_file, allow_growth=True)
> ```

Thank you!  It finally works for me.
